natural problem: A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3?
natural solution: There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and B :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..100}"
and h1 : "B = {x \<in> A. x mod 3 = 0}"
shows  "card B / card A = 33 / 100"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and B :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..100}"
and h1 : "B = {x \<in> A. x mod 3 = 0}"
shows  "card B / card A = 33 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "Consider two sets of integers, A and B. A contains all the integers from 1 to 100 inclusive. B contains all integers in A that are divisible by 3. What is the ratio of the size of set B to the size of set A? The final answer is $\frac{33}{100}$."

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..100} \<longrightarrow> f n = (n mod 3 = 0)"
shows  "card {n \<in> {1..100}. f n} / 100 = (33::real) / 100"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..100} \<longrightarrow> f n = (n mod 3 = 0)"
shows  "card {n \<in> {1..100}. f n} / 100 = (33::real) / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In the set of natural numbers from 1 to 100, find the proportion of numbers that are divisible by 3. The answer is 33 out of 100.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..100}"
shows  "card {m \<in> {1..100}. m mod 3 = 0} / card {1..100} = 33 / 100"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..100}"
shows  "card {m \<in> {1..100}. m mod 3 = 0} / card {1..100} = 33 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: What is the proportion of numbers from 1 to 100, inclusive, that are divisible by 3? Express your answer as a fraction. The answer is $\frac{33}{100}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 100 \<longrightarrow> p i = 1 / 100"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. \<not>(1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 100) \<longrightarrow> p i = 0"
shows  "sum p {i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 100 \<and> i mod 3 = 0} = 33 / 100"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 100 \<longrightarrow> p i = 1 / 100"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. \<not>(1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 100) \<longrightarrow> p i = 0"
shows  "sum p {i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 100 \<and> i mod 3 = 0} = 33 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The probability of each integer from 1 to 100 inclusive is 1/100 and the probability of all other integers is 0. What is the sum of the probabilities of the integers from 1 to 100 inclusive that are divisible by 3? The final answer is 33/100.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {x. x \<in> {1..100} \<and> x mod 3 = 0}"
shows  "measure (count_space {1..100}) A = 33 / 100"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {x. x \<in> {1..100} \<and> x mod 3 = 0}"
shows  "measure (count_space {1..100}) A = 33 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: What is the proportion of natural numbers between 1 and 100 inclusive that are divisible by 3? The final answer is $\frac{33}{100}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. P n = (n mod 3 = 0)"
shows  "card {n. P n \<and> 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100} / 100 = 33 / 100"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. P n = (n mod 3 = 0)"
shows  "card {n. P n \<and> 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100} / 100 = 33 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: What is the proportion of integers between 1 and 100 inclusive that are divisible by 3? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{33}{100}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
assumes h0 : "finite {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100}"
and h1 : "card {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100} = 100"
and h2 : "card {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = 33"
shows  "prob {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = 33 / 100"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
assumes h0 : "finite {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100}"
and h1 : "card {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100} = 100"
and h2 : "card {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = 33"
shows  "prob {n::nat. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = 33 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: What is the probability that a number between 1 and 100 (inclusive) is divisible by 3? The final answer is $33/100$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "nat set"
and E :: "nat set"
and P :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..100}"
and h1 : "E = {x \<in> S. x mod 3 = 0}"
and h2 : "P(A) = card(A) / card(S)"
shows  "P(E) = 33/100"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A number is selected at random from 1 through 100, inclusive.  What is the probability that the number is a multiple of 3? The final Answer is \dfrac{33}{100}
 ### Proof
 There are 100 numbers possible between 1 and 100. There are 33 multiples of 3 between 1 and 100: $(3,6,9,\ldots,99)=(1\times 3,2\times 3,3\times 3,\ldots,33\times 3)$.
 So the probability that a randomly selected number is a multiple of 3 is $\boxed{\dfrac{33}{100}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: "nat set"
and E :: "nat set"
and P :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..100}"
and h1 : "E = {x \<in> S. x mod 3 = 0}"
and h2 : "P(A) = card(A) / card(S)"
shows  "P(E) = 33/100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: The set $S$ consists of all natural numbers from 1 to 100. The set $E$ is a subset of $S$, containing only the numbers that are divisible by 3. The function $P$ is defined as the ratio of the cardinality (the number of elements) of a set $A$ to the cardinality of the set $S$. What is the value of $P(E)$? The final answer is $\frac{33}{100}$.
